Class KenKen

  • java.lang.Object
    • KenKen

  • public class KenKen
extends Object
    This class is used to check the structural and semantical integrity of a 3D-array kenken with respect to whether it encodes a valid KenKenTM puzzle and to solve it if possible.
    Version:
    2.0, 11/05/16
    Author:
    John Doe
    See Also:
    Example from Wikipedia and its solution

    • Method Detail

      • checkIntegrity

        public static int checkIntegrity(int[][][] kenken)
        Checks the structural integrity of the 3D-array kenken.

        Here, structural integrity is defined as:

        1. kenken is non-null and contains at least one entry, i.e. a "row" in the first dimension representing a "partition"
        2. each row (partition) contains a non-null 2D-array of type int[][] with at least two sub-entries of type int[]
        3. each sub-entry in a row (partition) is non-null and has length 2
        4. the first sub-entry in a row is a pair {result, operation}, where result is an integer number and operation is a char(acter)
        5. operation must be one of '+', '-', '/', '*', ' ' (whitespace)
        6. all other sub-entries (except for the first one) in a row must be pairs of non-negative int-numbers
        7. if operation is ' ' (whitespace), then exactly one sub-entry must follow the {result, operation}-pair
        8. if operation is '-' or '/', then exactly two sub-entries must follow the {result, operation}-pair
        9. if operation is '+' or '*', then at least two sub-entries must follow the {result, operation}-pair
        Parameters:
        kenken - data structure (3D array of ints) hopefully encoding a KenKenTM puzzle
        Returns:
        • 0, if all the conditions for structural integrity above are met
        • the number of the first condition not met (smallest number) otherwise

      • checkValidity

        public static int checkValidity(int[][][] kenken)
        Checks the semantical validity of the 3D-array kenken.

        The 3D-array kenken represents a semantically valid KenKenTM puzzle if

        1. it has structural integrity as defined for checkIntegrity(int[][][])
        2. it contains only non-overlapping partitions entirely covering a square field

        Each entry (i.e. "row" in the first dimension) of kenken denotes a partition.

        Each partition is defined in terms of a pair {result, operation} and a list of 2D-coordinates {row, column} (immediately following the {result, operation} pair) denoting a field in a KenKenTM diagram.

        Parameters:
        kenken - data structure (3D array of ints) hopefully encoding a KenKenTM puzzle
        Returns:
        • 1, if kenken has no structural integrity
        • 2, if there is overlapping between partitions or the partitions do not fully cover a square field
        • 0 otherwise

      • solve

        public static int[][] solve(int[][][] kenken)
        Tries to solve the KenKenTM puzzle encoded in the 3D-array kenken.

        A KenKenTM diagram is a square field of fixed edge length (say n).

        The KenKenTM is said to be solved, if each row resp. each column of the Kendoku diagram contains the numbers 1 to n exactly once such that result is the outcome of applying operation to all fields of the partition denoted by its list of 2D-coordinates {row, column}.

        • if operation is ' ' (whitespace), then result immediately denotes the value expected in the field
        • if operation is '-' or '/', then result is the difference (resp. quotient) of the two fields - both, the first or the second pair of coordinates might represent the subtrahend (resp. divisor)
        • if operation is '+' or '*', then result denotes the sum (resp. product) of all the fields in the partition
        Parameters:
        kenken - data structure (3D array of ints) hopefully encoding a KenKenTM puzzle
        Returns:
        • null, if kenken is illegal according to checkIntegrity(int[][][]) and checkValidity(int[][][]) or has no solution
        • 2D-array of ints (int[][]) containing any arbitrary solution otherwise
        See Also:
        Example from Wikipedia and its solution
